Pep Guardiola explains why Man City have struggled after terrific start The Manchester City coach also defended Claudio Bravo as his team prepare to take on West Ham Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now West Ham v City: Preview Share this video Get Manchester City FC   Could   
Pep Guardiola has shouldered the responsibility for Manchester City's form tailing off this season. 
An electric start saw the Blues win their first 10 games under their new manager in all competitions, setting the early pace in the Premier League and impressing in the Champions League. 
But the team did not react well to losing their first game and have been plagued by inconsistencies since their 2-0 defeat to Tottenham at White Hart Lane. 
Talk has changed from discussing a title challenge to a top-four battle , with Chelsea racing ahead of the pack to sit nine points clear of second place after their 1-1 draw with Liverpool. 
Guardiola admitted City's inconsistencies have left them with a big gap to top spot, and indicated he thought his players were more in sync with his ideas than they actually were. Read More How to follow West Ham vs City tonight 
"I think we learned and improved a lot in the beginning and then we stopped," he said. "I don't want to be humble or shy or something but it was maybe my mistake. 
"I believed we had it and they (the players) did not believe we had it. I'm pretty sure we started really good in many things and now we stopped. 
"You have to restart that. Our build-up is so fundamental in my vision of football. 
"When they attack the space, or when we attack in the counter-attacks, we create a lot of chances. We miss, after that, the last pass. It started in the Swansea game in the league when we won 3-1. We arrived 10 or 12 times for the last pass and we missed it. Raheem Sterling finally finished Swansea off in that game 
"The way we play, to build up from behind, we have a lot to improve. A lot. That's why it's nice. I still have the ambition, unfinished business." 
City have struggled with converting their chances and possession into goals, and have also struggled at the other end with Claudio Bravo seeing the last six shots on target fly straight into the net. 
Much was made of the decision to replace Joe Hart with the Barcelona goalkeeper and Bravo and Guardiola have been criticised with City's defence looking slacker than it was last season. Read More Man City forward Gabriel Jesus 'not a typical No.9', warns Man City star Pablo Zabaleta 
Coming to the goalkeeper's defence once more, the coach believes the Chilean will look better when his team-mates are more up to speed with the new style of playing. 
"Claudio has to pass good to his teammates and when they are not in their right position he does not pass good so it doesn't depend on Claudio," he added. 
"Claudio has the quality to do that, Willy as well, but it depends on the other one. If I want to pass the ball there but there is no player - I cannot pass the ball there." Read More
